Award.AwardTitle: Developing Resources for Research on Mollusks by Renovating Collection at Carnegie Museum of Natural History
Award.AbstractNarration: Research on mollusks relies on long-term access to collections such as those maintained by the Section of Mollusks at The Carnegie Museum of Natural History (CMNH). This project will significantly enhance present and future access by improving storage of this research collection. To improve storage, this project will move specimens from current perilous conditions, caused by normal acidic off-gassing from wooden cabinets, into more accessible archival metal storage cabinets with archival specimen boxes. This project will increase the present and future availability of the collection and associated specimen data to support collection-based research by biodiversity conservation organizations and agencies at the federal, state, and local levels. This project will increase public education by making specimens more readily available to science-based public outreach programs, including tours, exhibits, and collaborative activities with other museum components. The project will educate and train volunteers and undergraduate work-study students, who are likely to include members of underrepresented groups (the PI's 7-year track record shows that 20% of 142 volunteers have been from underrepresented minority or ethnic groups, and 7% have had disabilities). The mollusk collection at CMNH is a major resource of international significance, being the largest collection of northern Appalachian non-marine mollusks and one of the top five freshwater mussel collections. Historically significant, the collection vouchers 100 years of research. Examples of recent collection use include molecular and morphological systematic studies (including five by students), environmental monitoring, training for mussel surveyors, and museum exhibits. Any thorough study of North American mollusks would refer to this collection. Information on the CMNH Collection of Mollusks can be found at http://www.carnegiemnh.org/mollusks/collection.htm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At Carnegie Museum of Natural History, we accomplished the two major project goals of (1) improving accessibility to specimens for public visitors and researchers and (2) protecting specimens by transferring them from perilous to archival conditions. Improved access to specimens enhances the extensive potential for research, discovery, and visitor experience. The enhanced specimen storage conditions ensure specimen availability for public education and for researchers into the future, resulting in more research, knowledge, and publications.

The large collection of mollusks at Carnegie Museum of Natural History contains scientifically and historically valuable specimens that can never be replaced, but nearly half of the collection was previously on a second level that was not wheelchair accessible. Furthermore, for more than 100 years, the collection was stored in wooden cabinets, wooden drawers, and acidic cardboard specimen trays, which were state-of-the-art at the time, but we now understand that acidic vapors produced by wood can damage specimens by reacting with calcium carbonate in shells.

To solve the access and specimen conservation problems, Carnegie Museum renovated a more accessible space within the museum. Into this space we installed 73 new archival metal cabinets purchased by NSF, then transferred the dry mollusk specimens into the cabinets with archival aluminum drawers and archival specimen trays. Furthermore, we transferred all alcohol specimens into storage cabinets for flammable materials.

The enhanced access and specimen conservation is already benefiting public education and research both at Carnegie Museum and outside organizations. The enhancement allows researchers to gain access to specimens that they would otherwise lack. Examples of recent use by museum workers (not funded by but benefiting from this grant) include documenting snail distributions in Pennsylvania, Virginia, and New York, DNA studies of slugs, documenting a decline in the snail Anguispira alternata, species distribution predictive modeling, the Land Snails of Pennsylvania Atlas Project, and determining imperilment ranks for Pennsylvania’s land snails.

Outside of Carnegie Museum, agencies and organizations at the national, state, and local levels benefit from enhanced access and specimen conservation. These organizations, especially those working toward biodiversity conservation, use the collection to document changes in species distribution over time and use these data in forming policies. Organizations such as the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy and independent consultants also use our specimens, especially the freshwater mussels, to learn how to identify difficult or rare species.

The enhanced accessibility has increased our opportunities for bringing science to the public during behind-the-scenes tours and special programs such as Youth Naturalists, when the public sees research and curation in action. These experiences help to increase science literacy. Visitors frequently comment that the tour was the best part of their entire museum visit.

This project impacts society beyond science and technology in two main ways: (1) improving public knowledge and science literacy, and (2) playing a crucial role in improving the condition of the environment. Of the research sections at Carnegie Museum, the Section of Mollusks is one of the most visited by the public and as such represents the public face of research and collections. Our monthly behind-the-scenes tours, as well as other science-based and citizen science programs including summer camp events, engage and infect participants with enthusiasm for mollusks and the natural world.
